awd_titl_txt: High-level QM/MM free energy calculations and reaction path studies at affordable computational cost
awd_abstract_narration:
Henry Lee Woodcock of the University of South Florida is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop the next generation of accurate and efficient methodology to simulate reactive chemical systems in solution. Solvent plays a major role in governing chemical processes and must be taken into account to construct accurate models. It is much more difficult to study chemical reactions in solution than to study reactions of isolated or gas phase molecules. Woodcock and his coworkers focus on the development of open-sourced Web-based software (www.charmming.org) to facilitate molecular simulation. The software development efforts are tightly coupled to education and outreach activities aimed at making advanced molecular simulation techniques more accessible to modeling newcomers and the non-technical expert. Education and outreach related developments are incorporated into the physical chemistry curriculum at several universities.  Woodcock and his research group collaborate extensively with a leading expert in the field, Professor Stefan Boresch at the University of Vienna in Austria.  This research is cofunded by the Office of International Science and Engineering and the Computational Science and Engineering (CDS&E) program in the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

Accurately computing free energies is one of the most challenging problems facing chemists. It is well known  that solvent plays a major role in governing chemical processes and must be takeninto account to construct accurate models. The hybrid quantum mechanical / molecular mechanical (QM/MM) framework is the current tool of choice when accurate computations of macromolecular systems are essential. However, robust and efficient approaches that employ the high levels of computational theory needed to accurately describe many reactive processes  while also including explicit solvation effects and accounting for extensive conformational sampling are essentially non-existent.  The main goal this project is the development of techniques that mitigate current computational limitations related to accuracy, efficiency, and adequate sampling in such calculations. These methods are applied to study two key processes that are fundamental to understanding structure and stability across a range of solvated bio-organic compounds.

por.por_cntn:
Accurately computing free energies is one of the most challenging problems facing chemists. It is awell-known fact that solvent plays a major role in governing chemical processes and must be takeninto account to construct accurate models. The hybrid quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical(QM/MM) framework is the current tool of choice when accurate computations of macromolecular systemsare essential. However, robust and efficient approaches that employ the high levels of computationaltheory needed to accurately describe many reactive processes (i.e., ab initio, DFT), while alsoincluding explicit solvation effects and accounting for extensive conformational sampling areessentially non-existent.  The main goal of the current support work is the development of techniquesthat mitigate current computational limitations related to the accuracy, efficiency, and adequatesampling in such calculations. These methods are applied to study two key processes that arefundamental to understanding structure and stability across a range of solvated bio-organiccompounds.


The intellectual merit aspects of this award directly facilitated the development of multiple novel methodologies for carrying out QM/MM free energy simulations (FES). The first of these focused on extending the non-Boltzmann Bennett (NBB) method to changing computational levels of theory rather than simply alchemical states. This new method, termed vertical-NBB, resulted in a significant improvement in converging QM/MM FES. Unfortunately, we still observed significant deficiencies in accurately calculating free energies when different levels of theory resulted in disparate potential energy surfaces. To this end, we developed a more robust technique that incorporated non-equilibrium work (NEW) rather than typical simulation approaches. Utilizing NEW-type simulations in conjunction with QM/MM FES was a novel concept resulting in a peer-reviewed publication describing this in the most impactful journal in the physical chemistry discipline (J. Chem. Phys. Lett.) and a follow-up, with additional details, in the J. Comput. Chem. Ultimately, these techniques drew significant interest from the wider computational community and we were invited to write a review article in Methods in Enzymology. In addition to developing a more robust methodology to converge FES between disparate levels of theory, we also investigated ways to mitigate the vast differences themselves. This resulted in laying the groundwork of a framework to rapidly reparameterize low levels of theory (i.e., classical force fields) to more accurately reproduce the target, high, level of theory. This procedure is based on "force matching", where the idea is to use a machine learning model to generate improved force field parameters that "match" the forces that molecules experience on a high level of theory potential energy surface. The combination of the multiple techniques that were developed as part of this grant shows great promise in overcoming the aforementioned challenges in QM/MM FES and lays the groundwork for us to continue the development and application of these exciting techniques. 


In addition to the intellectual merit of this award, there was also a significant component that was related to outreach and education. These efforts included substantial work with professors at Georgetown University and Florida International University. The central part of this was related to the continued development of a web-based platform for easily setting up and carrying out molecular simulations while also tightly integrating that with education lessons that provided a basic introduction to this exceedingly complicated process. These tools were used multiple times in both graduate and undergraduate courses at Georgetown University and the University of South Florida, while a more extensive workshop was developed and run in collaboration with Prof. David Chatfield at Florida International University (https://casfaculty.fiu.edu/David.Chatfield/workshop/). Accompanying these courses and workshops were multiple tutorials that have been made available to the community and the great experiences that Dr. Fiona Kearns (a former graduate student, now a post-doc at UCSD, with the ambition to pursue a career in academia) gained in helping me develop much of this material.  Finally, a major outreach opportunity that would not have been possible without this award was the extensive international collaboration experience that two of my graduate students gained. Each of these (Dr. Kearns and Dr. Phillip Hudson) visited the University of Vienna (Austria) multiple times to work with my collaborator (Prof. Stefan Boresch). These experiences both enriched their academic education while also exposing them to the broader scientific world, in my opinion, an essential aspect to becoming a scientist in a world where global cooperation is becoming essential to solving the most challenging problems facing.
